subject: Communication
title: Can You Really Spot a Liar?
description: A micro-lesson that makes Can You Really Spot a Liar? usable.

hook.text: People think they can spot liars. Research says we're right about 54% of the time â€” barely better than a coin flip.

buildup.text: Police, judges, and psychologists all perform at roughly chance level when detecting deception in studies.

discovery.text: We look for the wrong cues: fidgeting, gaze aversion, and nervousness â€” which also appear in truthful anxious people.

twist.text: Liars don't always squirm. Skilled liars are often calmer than truth-tellers because they've rehearsed.

climax.text: No single cue reliably detects deception. The best approach looks for inconsistencies across multiple channels.

punchline.text: There's no Pinocchio's nose. Lie detection is hard for everyone.

quiz.question: How accurate are most people at detecting lies?
